webRendering.title: Client-Side Rendering
webRendering.description: The website is rendered in the browser or client. Then, a framework like Vue generates HTML elements after the browser downloads and parses all the JavaScript code containing the instructions to create the current interface.

benefits.name: Development speed
benefits.description: When working entirely on the client side, we don't have to worry about the server compatibility of the code.

benefits.name: Cheaper (no server needed)
benefits.description: Running a server adds a cost of infrastructure as you would need to run on a platform that supports JavaScript. We can host Client-only applications on any static server with HTML, CSS, and JavaScript files.

benefits.name: In-app user experience
benefits.description: Navigation between views is faster. After rendering the whole application and going from one view to another, it won't be re-downloaded, and you won't have to make more requests to the server.

benefits.name: Offline
benefits.description: Because code entirely runs in the browser, it can keep working while the internet is unavailable.

drawbacks.name: Performance
drawbacks.description: The user has to wait for the browser to download, parse and run JavaScript files. Depending on the network for the download part and the user's device for the parsing and execution, this can take some time and impact the user's experience.

drawbacks.name: Accessibility
drawbacks.description: Since the application relies on JavaScript to function, it can be difficult or impossible for users with JavaScript disabled or on devices with limited processing power to access the application.

drawbacks.name: SEO
drawbacks.description: Indexing and updating the content delivered via client-side rendering takes more time than a server-rendered HTML document. Search engine crawlers won't wait for the interface to be fully rendered on their first try to index the page. Your content will take more time to show and update in search results pages with pure client-side rendering.

useCases.name: Highly interactive websites
useCases.description: Websites that require a lot of user interaction, such as form submissions, real-time updates, and dynamic content.

useCases.name: Websites with a lot of dynamic data
useCases.description: Websites that display a lot of real-time analytics or data visualizations. For example, a website that displays weather information, stock prices, or news updates.

useCases.name: Websites with a lot of user-generated content
useCases.description: Websites that allow users to create and upload content, such as social media platforms, can benefit from CSR.

useCases.name: Websites that require offline functionality
useCases.description: Websites that need to function offline or in low-connectivity environments.

webRendering.title: Server-Side Rendering
webRendering.description:
This technique involves rendering the HTML of a webpage on the server before it is sent to the user's device. This can improve the perceived performance of a webpage, as the user's device does not need to spend time rendering the HTML. 
 SSR pages are generated on the server, and a populated HTML is served to your users, unlike CSR, which serves skeleton HTML and uses JavaScript on the client side to generate HTML. 
 This approach is commonly used with traditional multi-page applications, where the server generates a new HTML page for each request.

benefits.name: Improved performance for initial load
benefits.description: Since the initial HTML is generated on the server, it can be sent to the browser quickly, allowing the user to see something on the screen almost immediately, improving the initial load time.

benefits.name: Better SEO
benefits.description: Search engine crawlers can index the rendered HTML, making it more easily discoverable by search engines.

benefits.name: Accessibility
benefits.description: Since the rendered HTML is sent to the browser, it can be accessed by users with JavaScript disabled or on devices with limited processing power.

benefits.name: Improve security
benefits.description: You can easily use environment variables and perform sensitive operations such as database queries to populate the HTML files with data on the server.

drawbacks.name: Increased server load
drawbacks.description:
Since the server is responsible for rendering the HTML, it can put a lot of load on the server, particularly for large or complex applications. 
 It demands more performance from your servers to generate HTML, and the number of server requests is way higher compared to CSR mode as every page is generated from scratch.

drawbacks.name: Limited interactivity
drawbacks.description: Because the HTML is generated on the server, it can be more difficult to create a dynamic and interactive experience for the user.

drawbacks.name: JavaScript needed for dynamic content
drawbacks.description: If the website needs to have dynamic content, JavaScript is needed to handle it on client-side, which can slow down the loading of the application.

drawbacks.name: Not good for slow internet connection
drawbacks.description: If a user is on a slow internet connection, it may take longer for the HTML to load, leading to a poor user experience.

webRendering.title: Increased server load
webRendering.description: It demands more performance from your servers to generate HTML. The number of server requests is way higher.

webRendering.title: Build time
webRendering.description: The real disadvantage of static site generators is the total time it takes to build all the static pages.

webRendering.title: Small changes
webRendering.description: When changes that affect 1 page are published, it run the build process again.

webRendering.title: Inconsistent for real-time updates
webRendering.description: The first visitor to a page triggers revalidation, but first sees a fallback page with outdated data (stale page). Solution ISR 2.0 → On-demand ISR

webRendering.title: Flexibility: specific use case
webRendering.description: When the project requires using multiple rendering modes. A website with sections for different purposes, an admin area for the user, pages with real time data and pages with static content, text and images.

webRendering.title: Hybrid Rendering
webRendering.description: Combining SSR, CSR and/or SSG. This technique combines server-side and client-side rendering, where the initial HTML is rendered on the server, and then JavaScript is used to update the page dynamically.
